comments.html: How can you pass a parameter?
comments.name: Anonymous

comments.html: You cannot pass a parameter when using EEM applet, you need Tcl script to do that. I'll cover that in a future post.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Please show the example with the interactive tcl script - how to pass the parameter to the command
comments.name: lizu

comments.html: The complete example is posted here.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
ok but can you make a script with deals with such situation - sometimes when you put command you have to confirm it

like e.g reload
[confirm] ENTER
how to confirm command in the tcl script ?
comments.name: lizu

comments.html: I was able to figure out the reload specific solution. No luck about other prompty commands yet.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html: Yes reload is specific but other clear or delete commands which require confirmation are different maybe a interior variable some kind of event handler? I am still looking for this
comments.name: lizu

comments.html: The typeahead command worked for me in IOS release 12.4(15)T.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
The "cli command" lines are executed in a context of a different VTY line (EEM script opens a "console" session to execute them), so the "terminal monitor" command doesn't apply to your current session. I wrote a blog post about this, just search some more ;)

A tcl script executed with tcl command might do the trick (don't remember the details, it's been a long time). Yet again, I probably published at least one example of how that's done.
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Thanks for your reply! I tried the following TCL script:
puts [open "flash:debugSIPon" w+] {
exec "debug ccsip messages"
exec "terminal monitor"
}
when I execute it
tclsh flash:debugSIPon
I don't get any error, but no output to vty either.
Thanks
comments.name: Terrenos Sta Isabel

comments.html:
Don't use "exec", just include CLI commands in TCL script. See

http://wiki.nil.com/Executing_IOS_commands_from_Tcl_shell
comments.name: Ivan Pepelnjak

comments.html:
Thanks for the post!
I configured the following applet:
event manager applet DebugSIP
event none
action 1.0 cli command "debug ccsip messages"
action 2.0 cli command "terminal monitor"
!
I run it with:# event manager run DebugSIP
Yet I don't get any messages on the terminal..
Any idea why?
Thanks again,
Gabriel
comments.name: Gabriel Lema

comments.html:
I was finally able to combine tcl + alias to turn sip debug with just typing dsip, and turn it off with usip, thanks to http://blog.ipspace.net/2008/01/copy-text-files-into-router-flash.html and this one.
Thanks for your quick response!!
comments.name: Gabriel Lema
